chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: In this problem, we will determine if the company should accept either of the two investments based on their cashflow.

Payback period refers to the amount of time it takes before the initial investment is paid off by the investment. This means that in order for a company to accept an investment, the payback period of the investment must be lower than the payback cutoff of the company.

Before we solve for the payback period, we need to first solve for the accumulated cash flow for the break-even period of each investment.

For Investment A, we will only take the accumulated cash flow of Years 1 and 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Accumulated cash flow}&=\$12,000+\$17,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$19,000
\end{aligned}$$

For Investment B, we will take Years 1, 2, and 3:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Accumulated cash flow}&=\$11,000+\$13,000+\$16,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$40,000
\end{aligned}$$

We can then solve for the net cash flow in the recovery years by subtracting the accumulated cash flow from the initial investment.

For Investment A, the invested value is $\$35,000$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net cash flow in recovery years}&=\$35,000-\$19,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$16,000
\end{aligned}$$

For Investment B, the invested value is $\$45,000$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net cash flow in recovery years}&=\$45,000-\$40,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$5,000
\end{aligned}$$
